items.message:
River levels are high and rising slowly at the Cae Howel river gauge following recent heavy rainfall.  Flooding continues.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Predicted peaks:- Cae Howel 3.5 to 3.8m this afternoon, Sunday 09/01/22.   
No further significant rainfall is forecast.  We expect river levels to remain high until Monday, 10/01/22.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 10am on 10/01/22, or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Crew Green river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Flooding continues.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent the river from Shrewsbury to Upper Arley. Locations that may be affected are White Abbey, Coalbrookdale, Ironbridge and Bridgnorth. River Severn bankfull at White Abbey. Predicted Peaks:- Crew Green 5.2 to 5.4m Sunday morning, 09/01/22. No other gauge locations are forecast to reach their flood alert thresholds.   
No further significant rainfall is forecast.  We expect river levels to remain high until Sunday evening, 09/01/22.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 10am on 10/01/22, or as the situation changes.

floodArea.county: Shropshire, Staffordshire, Telford and Wrekin, Wrexham

items.message:
River levels are rising slowly at the Tern - Walcot river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible this afternoon Sunday 09/01/22.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington.   
No further significant rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high until Monday 10/01/22.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water.  
This message will be updated by 10am on Monday 10/01/22, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Rivers Clyst and Culm and their tributaries
items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly
items.message:
Flooding to low lying land and roads from the River Clyst is possible throughout Sunday.

Heavy rain over the weekend has caused river levels in the River Clyst to rise. Further showers are forecast throughout the weekend which will cause levels to remain higher than normal.

We expect flooding to affect Broadclyst and Clyst St Mary. Please take care near the areas of concern.
Do not walk or drive through flood water. Avoid low lying roads and footpaths, which may be flooded. 
 
Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the situation . 
  
This message will be updated on Monday morning.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Tamar, River Strat, River Neet, River Ottery, River Kensey

items.message: The risk of flooding from the Upper River Tamar has now reduced and the river has fallen below the level of concern. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

items.message:
The risk of flooding from the River Exe has now reduced, and river levels are falling below levels of concern. 
Further rain showers are forecast for the next few days, causing river levels to remain higher than normal. 
No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

items.description: South East Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Cam, River Wriggle, Barwick Stream, West Coker Stream

items.message: River levels have risen at the Sherborne Lake river gauge as a result of the ground being saturated and reacting to further rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 09/01/22.  We expect flooding to affect the Sparkford to Weston Bampfylde road and Deep Ford Lane, Chetnole. We expect river levels to remain above the Flood Alert threshold until tomorrow, 10/01/22. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens and closing flood gates. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 11:00 on Monday, 10/01/22, or as the situation changes.

items.message:

Further rain showers are forecast for the next few days, causing river levels to remain higher than normal. 
No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Horner Water, River Aller, Washford River, Hawkcombe Stream, Monksilver Stream, Doniford Stream

items.message: River levels have risen at the Beggearn Huish river gauge as a result of the ground being saturated and reacting to further rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 09/01/22. We expect flooding to affect the Horner Water, Rivers Aller and Washford, and the Hawkcombe, Monksilver and Doniford Streams and tributaries. We expect river levels remain above the Flood Alert threshold throughout today, 09/01/22. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens and closing flood gates. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 11:00 on Monday, 10/01/22, or as the situation changes.

This Flood Alert has been removed. 
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. No further rainfall is forecast. 
We continue to monitor the situation and we will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Please refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' web page for current river levels and remain safe and aware of your local surroundings.

River levels in Hellingly and Alfriston are still higher than normal, following Saturday's persistent rain. In Hellingly, both the Bull River and Cuckmere River are now falling. However, minor flooding will continue to affect fields and gardens on and near Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road, until approximately mid afternoon on Sunday 09/01/2022. The river has already returned to near normal past Mill Lane, Hellingly. In Alfriston the Cuckmere River will continue to slowly rise a small amount, until approximately 14:00 on Sunday 09/01/2022. Water will affect fields near North Street, River Lane, and the Old Clergy House, Alfriston, but thought unlikely to affect properties. Other than a little light drizzle early Tuesday morning, the next five days are forecast to remain dry. The Cuckmere River through Alfriston should have fallen significantly by Monday evening 10/01/2022. Please plan to avoid driving through routes susceptible to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 19:00 on 09/01/2022.

floodArea.county: Bath and North East Somerset, Wiltshire

items.message:
River levels have peaked and are falling on the Bristol Avon at Bradford-on-Avon and on the Semington Brook at Semington.
Only small amounts of rain are forecast for the next few days.
Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads between Melksham and Bathford. The flood gates at Holt Road may be closed.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated on Sunday evening.

River Levels in the Upper River Aire have now fallen below the flood risk threshold and are no longer filling the washlands. As there is no further significant rainfall forecast, this flood alert is no longer in force. Washlands at Snaygill Ings, Skipton and Cononley are draining steadily but will still contain water for some time as this process takes place. Please continue to take care if walking near washlands.

This flood alert is no longer in force. River levels have peaked at Earby Beck and are now falling below levels of concern. There may be scattered showers through the rest of today and tomorrow, however no further significant rainfall is forecast this weekend and we expect river levels to be able to continue to fall throughout the rest of Saturday and Sunday.

This warning is no longer in force. River levels have peaked at Walsden Water at levels below those forecasted, and are now falling below levels of concern. There may be scattered showers this evening, 08/01/2022, but these will be much less intense than this morning's rainfall and are not expected to cause a significant river level response.
 
No further significant rainfall is forecast this weekend and we expect river levels to be able to continue to fall throughout the rest of Saturday and Sunday.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Ouse, Burdyke, Holgate Beck, Blue Beck, River Foss, The Fleet

items.message:
River levels are rising on the River Ouse due to rainfall in the Dales over the last 24 hours. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Ouse, with low-lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Riverside footpaths and low-lying land in York and to the south as far as Naburn Lock, including Kings Staith, Queens Staith and South Esplanade. No further significant rainfall is forecast, however, river levels are likely to remain high throughout the day on Sunday, 09/01/2022.
We will continue to monitor levels closely. Our incident response staff are closing flood gates and checking defences along the River Ouse in York. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. Consider putting your flood plan into action. You should avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 21:00 on 09/01/2022, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely. We are continuing to see higher than normal water levels today, Sunday 9th January. Water levels continue to remain high, but are expected to soon start to drop back down to more normal levels. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry road in Horning. We are expecting levels to begin to drop through today and tomorrow. Take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and will update messages when necessary. We will update this message by 10am tomorrow, Monday 10th January.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
      
We continue to monitor the situation.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels are below the flood risk threshold. We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  No further significant rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Swale, Cod Beck, Bedale Beck

items.message: This flood alert for the Lower River Swale has now been issued as river levels have risen overnight at Maunby due to persistent rainfall over the last 24 hours. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is expected. Areas most at risk are low lying land and roads around Maunby, Catterick and Catterick Bridge. No further significant rainfall is forecast, however, river levels are likely to remain high throughout the day on Sunday, 09/01/2022. Our incident response staff are closely monitoring the forecast. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and do not walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 21:00, Sunday 09/01/2022, or as the situation changes. Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.
